Award.AwardTitle: Structure, Mechanism, and Regulation of Quinolinate Synthase, the First Committed Step in Bacterial NAD Biosynthesis

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit:
Nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD) is an essential and ubiquitous metabolite known primarily for its role as a co-substrate in a multitude of biological redox reactions. Recently, however, it has received significant recognition for its role in several non-redox reactions that impact cellular signaling and chromosome remodeling. In bacteria, NAD is biosynthesized from dihydroxyacetone phosphate and L-aspartate in a reaction catalyzed by the NadA/NadB enzyme system. NadA contains an oxygen-sensitive [4Fe-4S] cluster, which is required for the protein's function; however, the exact role that the iron-sulfur (Fe/S) cluster plays in catalysis is unclear. Moreover, the activity of the protein is regulated by a dithiol/disulfide redox switch, wherein the disulfide-form of the enzyme is approximately10-fold more active than the dithiol form. This behavior is interesting, because the concentrations of NAD and its associated metabolites are significantly greater in bacteria growing under aerobic conditions than under anaerobic conditions. The major goal of this project is to use X-ray crystallographic and spectroscopic methods to elucidate in detail how the Fe/S cluster functions in catalysis. A second area of emphasis is to elucidate the structural, chemical, and electronic changes that accompany reversible disulfide-bond formation and determine how these changes affect the protein's activity and cellular concentrations of NAD and its related metabolites.

Broader Impact:
This project will serve as a foundation for training graduate and undergraduate students in rigorous and quantitative scientific methods. Penn State is home to a wealth of expertise in metalloenzymology, especially as it pertains to physical, kinetic, and computational methods for studying iron-containing enzymes. The PI, in collaboration with other faculty here and at other institutions, will co-organize a biannual ten day workshop to train students in various physical methods for the characterization of metalloproteins.

This project is jointly supported by the Biomolecular Dynamics, Structure and Function Cluster in the Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences and the Chemistry of Life Processes program in the Chemistry Division.

POR.DRECONTENT:
INTELLECTUAL MERIT

The iron–sulfur (Fe/S)-dependent hydrolases are a class of enzymes that catalyze the dehydration or dehydration/rehydration of substrates containing hydroxyl groups. Interestingly, in all of these enzymes, the relevant substrate contains at least one carboxyl group, and almost all of the enzymes contain one [4Fe–4S] cluster, although there are reports of some that contain [2Fe–2S] clusters. The enzyme aconitase has been the paradigm for the Fe/S-dependent hydrolases; it catalyzes the reversible conversion of citrate to isocitrate via the intermediate, cis-aconitate.  A number of detailed mechanistic, spectroscopic, and x-ray crystallographic studies have provided key insight into the enzymatic mechanism of the enzyme. Aconitase contains a [4Fe–4S] cluster, in which three of its iron ions of are ligated by cysteinyl residues, while the fourth, unique iron, is coordinated by a water molecule or hydroxide ion. In the conversion of citrate to cis-aconitate, both the hydroxyl group and one oxygen atom of the C3 carboxylate of the substrate coordinate to the unique iron ion of the Fe/S cluster, resulting in an iron ion that goes from tetracoordinate to hexacoordinate. The C2 proton of the substrate is removed, allowing for dehydration to take place via an E1cb mechanism. 

Based on the aconitase paradigm it has been assumed that the major role of the [4Fe–4S] clusters of enzymes in the Fe/S-dependent hydrolase family is to coordinate to the hydroxyl group of the substrate that is lost concomitant with dehydration. My laboratory determined that both quinolinate synthase (NadA) and serine deaminase (LSD1) are members of the Fe/S-dependent hydrolase class of enzymes, showing that they each contain [4Fe–4S] clusters that are required for turnover. NadA catalyzes the condensation of dihydroxyacetone phosphate (DHAP) and iminoaspartate (IA) to yield quinolinic acid (QA), while LSD1 catalyzes the conversion of L-serine to pyruvate and ammonia. Although the substrates (or intermediates) for both of these reactions contain carboxylate groups as well as a hydroxyl group that is lost upon dehydration, unlike aconitase both the carboxyl group and hydroxyl group cannot be bound to the unique iron ion at the same time because of geometric constraints. Therefore, one major goal of this project is to assess which of these functional groups interacts with the Fe/S cluster, which has the potential to transform the paradigm for the role of Fe/S clusters in this class of enzymes.

With this award, we solved structures of NadA and LSD1 that impacted tremendously on our understanding of these enzymes. In the structure of NadA with QA, we found that QA binds to the unique iron ion of the cluster through its N1 atom and C2 carboxylate group. This binding arrangement places the C5 OH group in the precursor to QA away from the iron ion, suggesting that the C5 OH group does not coordinate to the cluster in the step in which it is eliminated. We also solved structures of NadA in the presence of DHAP and IA. Interestingly, both substrates bind to the Fe/S cluster in an overlapping fashion. We used spectroscopy to show that IA preferentially binds to the cluster and can displace DHAP. We also solved the structure of NadA in the presence of a species that we believe is an intermediate in the reaction. In this intermediate, the C5 OH group is already lost. This finding was completely unexpected, because it had been previously thought that loss of the C5 OH group takes place in the last step of the reaction, and that the OH group coordinates to the cluster in this step. 

My laboratory also determined that Escherichia coli NadA undergoes redox regulation, wherein two cysteines in a CxxC motif are reversibly oxidized to a disulfide bond. When the disulfide bond is present, the activity of the enzyme is more than 10-fold higher than the activity when the cysteines exist as sulfhydryls. We also found that NadA from Mycobacterium tuberculosis also is regulated in the same fashion through cysteines in a CxC motif. 

 Lastly, we solved the structure of LSD1 and used spectroscopy to show that serine coordinates to the unique iron ion of the cluster through its side-chain OH group.

BROADER IMPACTS

This project served as the basis for our training session on anaerobic protein purification and quantitative mass spectrometry that we held as a part of Penn State's Workshop in Bioinorganic Chemistry, which we hold every two years. This workshop brings in experts in various physical and spectroscopic techniques used in bioinorganic chemistry from the U.S. and Europe, and the student and postdoctoral trainees who participate come from all over the U.S., Europe, and the world. This project also was used to train a number of graduate students, research scientists and postdoctoral scholars. Most notably, it was used to train a high school student who graduated from college with a degree in chemistry and who is now a graduate student.
